page.title: All your base are belong to us

rev.diff:
Line 25: Line 25:
Due to its immense popularity, the phrase or some variation of the lines from the game has been seen in innumerable articles, books, comics, clothing, movies, radio shows, songs, television shows, video games, webcomics, and websites. However, few have actually drawn any legitimate media attention. A selection of those that have garnered such coverage follows; a [[Google]] search will turn up thousands more hits on individual websites.
Due to its immense popularity, the phrase or some variation of the lines from the game has been seen in innumerable articles, books, comics, clothing, movies, radio shows, songs, television shows, video games, webcomics, and websites. However, few have actually drawn any legitimate media attention. A selection of those that have garnered such coverage follows; a [[Google]] search will turn up thousands more hits on individual websites.
â
*On [[2001-02-23]], [[Wired (magazine)|''Wired'']] provided an early report on the phenomenon in an article entitled âWhen Gamer Humor Attacks,â which covered everything from the Flash animation to its spread through [[e-mail]] and Internet forums to [[T-shirt]]s bearing the phrase.<ref>{{cite web | author=Benner, Jeffrey | year=2001-02-23 | url=http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,42009,00.html | title=When Gamer Humor Attacks | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
+

â
*In the [[FoxTrot]] [[comic strip]] on [[2001-03-12]], Jason Fox (the [[nerd]]y youngest child) began to shout, âAll your base are belong to us!â confusing his parents. [[Bill Amend]] has been known to incorporate âgeek cultureâ into his comic strips, such as the fictional [[MMORPG]] âWorld of <!-- READ THIS: Please DO NOT CHANGE THIS to âWarcraftâââWarcraftâ is a fictional game from the comic strip, obviously a joke mixing Warcraft and Everquest. Thanks for your cooperation. -->Warquest.â<ref>{{cite web | author=Amend, Bill | year=2001-03-12 | url=http://homepage.mac.com/brossow/wikipedia/foxtrot_aybabtu.gif | title=FoxTrot | format=GIF | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>

[[Bill Amend]] has been known to incorporate âgeek cultureâ into his comic strips, such as the fictional [[MMORPG]] âWorld of <!-- READ THIS: Please DO NOT CHANGE THIS to âWarcraftâââWarcraftâ is a fictional game from the comic strip, obviously a joke mixing Warcraft and Everquest. Thanks for your cooperation. -->Warquest.â<ref>{{cite web | author=Amend, Bill | date=[[2001-03-12]] | url=http://homepage.mac.com/brossow/wikipedia/foxtrot_aybabtu.gif | title=FoxTrot | format=GIF | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
*In the game [[Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos]] and its expansion pack, [[Warcraft III: The Frozen Throne]], the cheat code âAll Your Base Are Belong To Usâ leads to automatic victory and âSomebody Set Up Us The Bombâ leads to automatic defeat.
*In the game [[Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos]] and its expansion pack, [[Warcraft III: The Frozen Throne]], the cheat code âAll Your Base Are Belong To Usâ leads to automatic victory and âSomebody Set Up Us The Bombâ leads to automatic defeat.
â
*On [[2002-01-06]], an episode of the television show ''[[Futurama]]'' (â[[Anthology of Interest II]],â episode #403) featured a segment in which the robot Beserk said, "All your base are belong to us."<ref>{{cite web | author=Morton, Lewis | year=2002-01-06 | url=http://www.imsdb.com/transcripts/Futurama-Anthology-Of-Interest-II.html | title=âAnthology Of Interest IIâ Transcript at IMSDb | work=Internet Movie Script Database | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
+
*On [[2002-01-06]], an episode of the television show ''[[Futurama]]'' (â[[Anthology of Interest II]],â episode #403) featured a segment in which the robot Beserk said, "All your base are belong to us."<ref>{{cite web | author=Morton, Lewis | date=[[2002-01-06]] | url=http://www.imsdb.com/transcripts/Futurama-Anthology-Of-Interest-II.html | title=âAnthology Of Interest IIâ Transcript at IMSDb | work=Internet Movie Script Database | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
â
*On [[2003-04-01]], in [[Sturgis, Michigan]], seven men aged 17 to 20 placed signs all over town that read, "All your base are belong to us. You have no chance to survive make your time." They said they were playing an [[April Fool's Day|April Fool's]] joke by mimicking the famous Flash animation that ubiquitously depicted the slogan. Not many people who saw the signs were familiar with the joke, however. Many residents were upset that the signs appeared while the U.S. was at [[2003 invasion of Iraq|war with Iraq]], and police chief Eugene Alli said the signs could be âa borderline terrorist threat depending on what someone interprets it to mean.â<ref>{{cite web | author=Doyle, Holly | year=2003-04-04 | url=http://wwmt.com/engine.pl?station=wwmt&id=468&template=breakout_local.html | title=Men arrested for âAll Your Baseâ prank | work=WWMT â Digital Channel 3 | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
+
*On [[2003-04-01]], in [[Sturgis, Michigan]], seven men aged 17 to 20 placed signs all over town that read, "All your base are belong to us. You have no chance to survive make your time." They said they were playing an [[April Fool's Day|April Fool's]] joke by mimicking the famous Flash animation that ubiquitously depicted the slogan. Not many people who saw the signs were familiar with the joke, however. Many residents were upset that the signs appeared while the U.S. was at [[2003 invasion of Iraq|war with Iraq]], and police chief Eugene Alli said the signs could be âa borderline terrorist threat depending on what someone interprets it to mean.â<ref>{{cite web | author=Doyle, Holly | date=[[2003-04-04]] | url=http://wwmt.com/engine.pl?station=wwmt&id=468&template=breakout_local.html | title=Men arrested for âAll Your Baseâ prank | work=WWMT â Digital Channel 3 | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
â
*In February 2004, an automated [[news ticker]] on [[News 14 Carolina]], a North Carolina cable channel, was â[[Hack (technology slang)|hacked]]â to display the message on television.<ref>{{cite web | author=Poulsen, Kevin | year=2004-03-05 | work=The Register | url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/03/05/wags_hijack_tv_channels_onscreen/ | title=Wags hijack TV channel's on-screen ticker | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
+
*In February 2004, an automated [[news ticker]] on [[News 14 Carolina]], a North Carolina cable channel, was â[[Hack (technology slang)|hacked]]â to display the message on television.<ref>{{cite web | author=Poulsen, Kevin | date=[[2004-03-05]] | work=The Register | url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/03/05/wags_hijack_tv_channels_onscreen/ | title=Wags hijack TV channel's on-screen ticker | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
â
*When Google launched [[Google Base]] in October 2005, the phrase was twisted into âAll Your Base Are Belong To Googleâ by search industry watchers such as [[John Battelle]].<ref>{{cite web | author=Battelle, John | year=2005-10-25 | url=http://battellemedia.com/archives/001960.php | title=base.google.com (Or...All Your Base Are Belong To Google) | work=John Battelle's Searchblog | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref> Furthermore, in Google's [http://www.google.com/intl/xx-hacker/ Hacker Translation], the âPersonalized Homeâ link has been translated into â4LL `/0|_||2 B453,â which is [[Leet]] for âAll Your Base.â
+
*When Google launched [[Google Base]] in October 2005, the phrase was twisted into âAll Your Base Are Belong To Googleâ by search industry watchers such as [[John Battelle]].<ref>{{cite web | author=Battelle, John | date=[[2005-10-25]] | url=http://battellemedia.com/archives/001960.php | title=base.google.com (Or...All Your Base Are Belong To Google) | work=John Battelle's Searchblog | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref> Furthermore, in Google's [http://www.google.com/intl/xx-hacker/ Hacker Translation], the âPersonalized Homeâ link has been translated into â4LL `/0|_||2 B453,â which is [[Leet]] for âAll Your Base.â
â
*On [[2006-06-01]], the video hosting website [[YouTube]] was taken down temporarily for maintenance. The phrase "ALL YOUR VIDEO ARE BELONG TO US" appeared below the YouTube logo as a placeholder while the site was down. Some users believed the site had been hacked, leading the host to add the message "No, we haven't be hacked. Get a sense of humor."<ref>{{cite web
+

The phrase "ALL YOUR VIDEO ARE BELONG TO US" appeared below the YouTube logo as a placeholder while the site was down.
